intro: Nothoscordum hirtellum subsp. lorentzii, commonly known as the Lorentz's wild garlic, is a flowering plant native to parts of Central and South America. It is a member of the Amaryllidaceae family and is characterized by its fragrant, garlic-like scent. The plant typically grows in moist, shaded environments such as forest floors or stream banks. It produces clusters of white to pale pink flowers that bloom in the spring. Its leaves are broad, lance-shaped, and often have a hairy texture, which gives it its specific epithet "hirtellum."
